comments.author: VIIflegias

comments.text:
It goes without saying that Psycho is a classic, a ground breaker, and 
supremely unforgettable and creepy. If a film can impact viewers so deeply 
that every single time they take a shower they have a brief moment where 
this film crosses their mind, then that is one masterful film indeed. It's 
a classic in every sense of the word, and yes, definitely a masterpiece 
(even if I prefer the first half over the second, I just love Janet Leigh's 
performance.) With that said, I think that Gus Van Sant's Psycho is overly 
shat upon. Just because a film is a classic, doesn't mean another artist 
isn't allowed to experiment with it. And while yes, it is nearly shot for 
shot, Sant still adds his own personal and unique touches to it, like 
subliminal imagery, equally beautiful cinematography, and ever so small 
tweaks to key scenes and moments. Especially in this scene, in the 98 
version a birdcage is added, and the sounds of flapping birds and squawks 
can be heard, and the lighting is also a tad different casting disorienting 
heavy shadows. I also like how Sant didn't up the gore or add any cheap 
scares for a modern audience, he simply reworked the material with his 
individual style and presented it to a modern audience (which he has stated 
was the main reason he did the film in the first place, to bring the film 
to a younger, modern, audience who wouldn't seek out the original.) I think 
it's highly underrated. But I know I'm in the minority.﻿
comments.author: Jacob Zembower

comments.text:
Undeniably a great movie. But this is one of the weakest scenes in the 
whole film. The editing at such a pivotal moment is a bit lacking. Miles is 
shocked before Perkins even makes it to the door. And Perkins is struggling 
to get his wig to drop to the floor.  Hitchcock dropped the ball on this 
one.﻿

comments.author: Tahj Parks

comments.text:
I think the fact that the film was so stripped back, and 
focuses predominantly on the psychological damage that can happen inside a 
person's mind, resulted in the film striking a particular cord with me. 
It's not the super natural that scares me, it's the human mind and how it 
can become poisonous and lead us to do evil things. THIS is why the film is 
so good and why it's a timeless classic. It didn't need anything but the 
story line and a couple of actors. ﻿

high budget and the special effects are fairly dated but yet, I showed this

the shower scene.

I guess what ruins a couple of the scenes from this is not the fact that 
there's been movies which have spoiled us on blood and gore and fights but 
rather the fact that before I've seen Psycho I've seen about 12 different 
parodies of the shower scene (including one done with Sylvester and 
Tweety...)﻿

comments.author: Owen Kyte

comments.text:
This movie still holds up pretty well in my view. People tend to forget 
that it was a genuine twist that Norman was Mother when the movie first 
came out, just like how originally, it was a twist that Dr Jekyll and Mr 
Hyde were the same person. If you look at the movie objectively, you can 
see that there are only very subtle hints to the true nature of Mother, 
nothing obvious or cliche.﻿

comments.text:
These comments amaze me.  People judging a movie they haven't seen all the 
way through.  Discussions about a TV show that has nothing to do with 
Hitchcock's original vision.  Television and all the blood and gore of 
horror movies since Psycho have muddled the minds of people too young to 
appreciate the original.﻿

of movies by tossing them so mindlessly into the dumpster (many of which 
they skip over or just not see) and in stark contrast throw this movie upon 
a golden pedestal.

comments.author: Katelyn Normington

comments.text:
I always thought the part where Norman hears her scream and comes running 
in, finally revealing the reality of the situation, to be the most 
frightening part of the film.  The look on his face is absolutely 
horrifying.  I often wonder why he didn't put up a fight against Sam Loomis 
when he was "mother" but moments before as Norman he managed to get the 
upper hand on Loomis.  Maybe he was just having a breakdown since the 
reality of everything was becoming clear to more than just himself.  ﻿

comments.text:
Well what I believe is that Norman and his mother had a very love-hate 
relationship as portrayed in the A&E TV show but Norma always knew he was a 
psycho while Norman thought she was the crazy one. But what I believe ends 
up happening is that they end up having sex, I forgot where I heard this 
but I'm pretty sure it happens because in the show she tries to make Norman 
jealous by sleeping with officer shelby, he gets angry because he 
hallucinates, like in the show, kills his mother and then takes over her 
identity while believing she is actually alive. pretty much what the person 
above said about split personality.

comments.text:
Some people have complained about the acting, and while I agree that Vera 
Miles and John Gavin's acting are dated, Anthony Perkin's acting holds up 
extremely well. He was a wonderful, snake like tension in his physicality, 
as if his nervous system doesn't know what to do with himself His twisting 
at the end, with his mouth hanging open with no sound, is supremely 
disturbing; ﻿

comments.author: Orson Durkin

comments.text:
I like the story of Norman Bates and especially the way in which the 
television series Bates Motel has been rebooting it. I plan to watch this 
film in it's entirety eventually but I must say this is a very 
disappointing ending. It took virtually no effort to stop Norman in his 
"Mother" persona.

I would have like to have seen an actual struggle. Perchance have them 
fight and Norman is winning and then kills Sam and right after Sam dies/is 
dying Lila knocks Norman out or at least knocks him out of his "Mother" 
persona by using a weapon to bash him behind the head. Something like this 
to make the ending more dramatic and exciting rather than so disappointing.

If you like comedy, please view our channel and sub us if you like our 
videos! xD﻿
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text:
+Gordon Scroggins This movie is based on the real life murders by Ed Gein 
in Plainfield Wisconsin in 1957. Then a book was written about it shortly 
after words.  I was only seven at the time, but I vaguely remember it. 
Later on there were pictures in the Enquire Magazine.  That magazine was a 
lot different back then.  It was mostly gory stuff.
comments.author: Christine Gruenberg

comments.text:
This was also based off of a novel. Alfred Hitchcock is one of the original 
names in horror/thriller films. This is a classic and great piece of work. 
To this day it gives me chills from beginning to end.
comments.author: Gordon Scroggins

comments.text:
+Blaaz101 Sorry for taking so long to reply.

I'm aware the scare or creepiness is suppose to be psychological and it's 
not due to gory or how much of a physical threat Norman is when he becomes 
"Mother" but don't you feel Norman being very easily subdued at the end was 
anti-climatic? A young child could have put up a better struggle.

I feel the director and/or script writer should have had Norman either 
kill, injure or at least put up a good struggle against Sam and have Lila 
knock out Norman from behind. Then the film continues as it is.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text:
+Johnny Aguirre TV Okay, the whole reason why this movie was so terrifying 
was because its scares were psychological in nature. The horror of just how 
messed up someone in the head must be to commit such unspeakable atrocities 
is what makes it so entrancing, and the reveal at the end shows just how 
out of touch with reality and beyond reason the psycho truly is. 
Complaining about there not being a big fight the end is completely missing 
the point. The point was not that he was a massive physical threat, the 
point was that he was a deeply disturbed person whose sanity was fractured 
long ago, and as a result is a threat to himself and to others. It's not 
the kind of movie that's about big fights or struggles, and demanding it to 
be like that is silly.
comments.author: Blaaz101

comments.text: Ya sure.
comments.author: TheNewRiflemanBob

comments.text: i like the bates motel television show if it's any consolation :)
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text: Some people will never be satisfied.
comments.author: TheNewRiflemanBob

comments.text:
I always thought of the film Psycho to be a horror film. And according to 
IMDb it falls under the category of horror, mystery and thriller.

I just dislike how easy it was to stop Norman in this scene. I would have 
preferred for Norman to have put up a fight and kill or almost kill the man 
who grabs him in this scene.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text:
+Johnny Aguirre TV You missed the point of this scene and the movie 
overall. Its not a slasher where you have a killer murdering people at 
every corner. This film is a psychological thriller and this last scene was 
meant to shock the audience. The shock value is the real climax. If you 
want to see a crazy butcher then just watch the saw movies.
comments.author: TheNewRiflemanBob

comments.author: Finozzi96

comments.text:
From what I researched online Psycho 2 & 3 have decent reviews from 
critics. But according to Wikipedia, initial reviews of the first Psycho 
film were mixed.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text: I honestly didn't even know there was a Psycho 1 and 2. Must've been bad.
comments.author: aesixonline

comments.text:
+aesixonline That's correct and so Norman was beating up Dylan, which was 
good to see for I hope Norman (especially when he is "Mother") becomes a 
true threat.

He could learn unarmed and/or armed combat in a future season. It's even 
more possible considering the fact he was kidnapped last season so perhaps 
he will learn martial arts or how to use weapons.

Bates Motel has stayed true to the 1st film (I don't know much about Psycho 
2 & 3) but it has deviated from it. In the original film Norma moves and 
owns a motel because of her boyfriend, Norma doesn't have any siblings nor 
does he have temper issues like young Norman in Bates Motel.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text:
The second time they fought, Dylan was tackled and mounted, it's hard for 
most people to avoid getting punched in the face repeatedly once mounted... 
If you watch UFC fights, most fights end once someone is mounted and 
getting punched.

And the point I'm trying to make is that Norman does not become more 
formidable as we see in this video. I could see how he would become a 
greater threat if he were to train in hand to hand combat, but he doesn't 
ever(from the original storyline), and they haven't deviated from the 
original story yet.
comments.author: aesixonline

comments.text:
+aesixonline He could become formidable though even if he remained thin. 
Having martial art skills while he is "Mother" or even just having 
adrenaline rushes and always having a weapon with him while he is "Mother" 
could fix things.

I don't think Dylan was holding back when Norman attacked him the second 
time. He was getting punched multiple times in the face while on the floor 
and began bleeding. I hope they continue to show Norman can handle himself 
in a fight and I hope they show he do even better when in his mother 
persona.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV

comments.text:
I dunno... everytime Norman fights Dylan, Norman attacks him with intent to 
kill while you can tell Dylan holds back. At teh end of the day, Norman is 
just a scrawny little kid, and it definitely shows. As we see in Psycho, 
he's still scrawny as a man who is easily overcome by the man.
comments.author: aesixonline

comments.text:
+aesixonline That is mostly not entirely true. Norman was beating up Dylan 
and only stopped beating him because Norma revealed the identity of Dylan's 
father. 

I'd hope the TV series continues to make him more capable of putting up a 
good fight whenever he attacks or defends himself as both Norman and 
"Mother". Especially "Mother" was I think somewhat easily defeated by Caleb 
who was unarmed while Norman in his "Mother" trace had a knife.

I know and that is why I excuse the fake looking fall when Norman slays the 
detective and the fake looking cuts the victims receive from knife slashes. 
The final scene could have been done better though. Even Bates Motel Norman 
who like I said in my last paragraph was to an extent easily defeated by 
Caleb at least attempted to attack/kill him. Norman in this scene didn't 
put up any fight at all and I personally find it disappointing. I like for 
horror (& action) films to end with a great final fight and/or chase 
sequence.
comments.author: Johnny Aguirre TV
